context_quality.assessment: REFLECT provided minimal context - no prior domain learnings were effectively utilized despite previous runs encountering the same 404 error. The execution_learning directory shows this is iteration 2 with known URL failures, but this wasn't surfaced as actionable context.
gaps: Failed to highlight the known ESPN URL 404 issue from previous run (dsl_iteration_1 had same failure)
No guidance on alternative data sources despite previous fetch failures
Missing focus on data source validation/reliability patterns
No warning about repeating the same failed approach

agency_effectiveness.assessment: ACT reused cached code that was known to fail at data retrieval, showing no adaptation to previous failures. The code structure is sound (proper error handling, merge logic, conditional tips generation) but the fundamental data source problem went unaddressed.
what_worked: Proper preservation of existing data structure (0 games preserved correctly)
Correct conditional logic for coaching tips generation (skipped when no new games)
Good error handling that prevented crashes and logged the 404 issue
Sound merge and deduplication logic (would work with valid data)
what_failed: Did not attempt alternative data sources despite known URL failure
Used cached code without validating if the data source issue was resolved
No proactive URL validation before attempting full scrape
ESPN URL endpoint appears incorrect (id/2359 may be wrong team ID)

key_issues: No game data retrieved due to 404 error at data source
ESPN URL returning 404 - either wrong endpoint or team ID incorrect
Cannot generate coaching tips without actual game data
Data source reliability is blocking all downstream functionality
suggestions: Verify the correct ESPN URL structure or use alternative data source (World Rugby, official Springboks website)
Add URL validation or fallback data sources for resilience
Implement data source health check before parsing
Add logging to track data source failure patterns
Distinguish between temporary network issues and permanent URL problems

strategic_insights: The loop is stuck in a cycle: using cached code that fails at the same data source step repeatedly without adaptation
Domain success depends entirely on data source accessibility - need fallback strategy
Code structure quality is high, but data acquisition strategy is brittle (single point of failure)
REFLECT-ACT feedback loop is broken: previous failures aren't triggering alternative approaches
VERIFY is identifying the right issues but recommendations aren't being incorporated into next ACT phase
recommendations_for_next_run: REFLECT should explicitly flag 'ESPN URL has failed in previous 2 runs - MUST try alternative data source' as priority focus
ACT should research and implement alternative Springbok data sources (World Rugby API, official Springboks stats, alternative ESPN URLs with correct team IDs)
Add data source validation step: test URL accessibility before attempting full scrape logic
Implement fallback chain: primary source (ESPN corrected) → secondary source (World Rugby) → tertiary source (official team site)
Include sample/mock data as ultimate fallback to allow testing of downstream logic (coaching tips generation)
Add domain learning: 'Web scraping requires URL validation and multiple source options for reliability'
